moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6: Philidor's Defense isn't supposed to lead to quick, smashing wins by BLACK. But with the genius of Alekhine, anything is possible!
moves.3. Bc4 Nc6 4. c3: Too slow, and interferes with the development of the QN. Against Alekhine, you can't make these kind of small mistakes!
moves.4... Bg4: Alekhine was never one to be passive.
moves.5... Qe7 6. Ng5: This attack is easily repulsed, as the Q-side pieces are still undeveloped.
moves.6... Nh6 7. Bxf7+ Nxf7 8. Nxf7 Qxf7: White's "attack" is gone. Now Alekhine will prepare a devastating counterstrike.
moves.9. Qxb7: Removing the Q from the defense, his only active piece. White would have been better served with a move such as 9 P-Q3, allowing the development of his Q-side pieces with B-K3 and N-Q2.
moves.9... Kd7 10. Qxa8: At least he has the consolation of winning some material before being buried by Black's coming onslaught.
moves.10... Qc4: Threatening mate on the move with ...Q-K7! White's undeveloped Q-side is useless.
moves.13. d3 Qxd3: Sacrificing the Knight as well. But if mate is in the offing...
moves.14. cxd4 Be7: White overlooks the threat. 15 K-B2 is the only way to prolong the game.
moves.15... Bh4#: Proving that material is less important than skill. Well done by the young Alekhine.
